meanings.definition: To catch in or as if in a trap.
meanings.sent1: The spider tried to entrap the fly in its web.
meanings.sent2: The hunter set up a trap to entrap the wild animal.
meanings.sent3: The clever fox managed to entrap the clumsy rabbit in a game of hide and seek.
meanings.sent4: Her words seemed to entrap him in a web of lies.
meanings.sent5: The detective used a clever plan to entrap the criminal.

meanings.definition: To lure into a compromising situation.
meanings.sent1: The scammer tried to entrap unsuspecting victims with promises of easy money.
meanings.sent2: She felt someone was trying to entrap her into revealing her secrets.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kids tried to entrap their teacher in a prank.
meanings.sent4: The spy was entraped into a dangerous mission by the enemy.
meanings.sent5: The politician was careful not to be entrapped by the media.
